author: noblesavage
title: The Holy Grail of Lego sets!
review: I always envied the kid down the street that had this set and dreamed of owning it some day. I finally found one a few years ago from a good seller in Germany. Containing the most coveted classic elements, this set has excellent playability and is the pride of my collection!

author: thebrickbuster
title: This is Classic
review:
I got this set when I was 10 years old. I saved up for months. This set, set the bar for all the space sets to come.This was also the start of the cool minifigs.This was one of the best value for money and included many unique elements going away from the basic ones. I really liked the cockpit design and opening cargo doors which releases the little vehicle.
Definately in my top 10.
Great achivement LEGO.

author: veector
title: Best of the Best
review:
If you grew up with Classic Space like I did, this was the "have to have" set.

Pros

  • Large model
  • Small buggy/car which deploys from the back
  • Includes 2 baseplates

Cons

  • The companion base building is tiny
  • Wish it was bigger?

I can't say how many hours I spent playing with the model. Way too many and even after all these years, this model still conjures memories of great times playing with LEGO.

author: villicus
title: Grey!
review:
Being a child i didnt like to build it  because it had so many confusing grey parts. But once you have finished, it was pure joy. Until now, in my opinion, its the most impressive of all space sets. It has a great playability, its not overboarded with useless details but still with the perfect amount of them, so it is really something special. The big brother of the LL918 it was.
The space station is nice also, and the little buggy was increasing the playability of it. 4 minifigs and some walkie talkies, what more should you want? Maybe lego star wars is nice, but this is the thing for me ;)

author: demasoni
title: To this day still one of the best
review: I got this set for my 8th birthday in 1979 and i still have it today. I never get tired of looking at it 29 years later and i'm so glad i never let my mom give it away. It truly is a classic set that can stand up to any new lego set today.

author: Wolf_99
title: Awesome
review: I have recently purchased this set to complete my classic space collection. growing up I always wanted this set but never got it. I love building it with my son, we spend lots of time playing with this set and other classic space sets, my son and I enjoy all the minifigs and the small buggy. I do not regret paying a little bit more for this set and I think all the parts are worth every pennies that I payed

author: skinnylawyer
title: Hard to find, and completely worth it.
review:
I recently went on an eBay bidding spree that more than doubled my Classic Space collection, and among them was this set, Galaxy Explorer. Back in my childhood, Set 483, Alpha-1 Rocket Base, was my only Space set, but I knew of many other gorgeous contemporary Space sets, and would have loved to have the Galaxy Explorer. Well, over a quarter of a century later and as a grown-up, I finally have Galaxy Explorer as part of my lunar base, and I am very happy about it! While my example has some play wear and many pieces yellowed due to sun exposure, it is still presentable, and unlike most examples, 100% complete.

Instructions

The instruction booklet is quite similar to those found in modern-day grownup-grade Lego sets, in that each step lists the types and quantities of pieces necessary. Considering the complexity of this set, I found that information very helpful. The booklet builds the spaceship first, then the control tower, and finally the buggy.

Parts

Typical early Classic Space, with lots of light gray, blue, and transparent yellow. Many light gray parts are sloped/diagonal, to make up the distinctive shape of the spaceship, which somewhat resembles the Star Destroyers from the contemporary Star Wars movies.

Lots of round nozzle type pieces for the engines, which would become handy if I wanted to rebuild the spaceship into a different design as a MOC.

A fair number of parts are printed/embossed, and the markings are quite durable.

Minifigures

Four classic astronaut minifigures are included: two red, and two white. They also come with various tools, including a pair of walkie-talkies, a wrench, and a gun. This set alone can make for many different scene possibilities due to the four astronauts being able to perform many different roles.

The build

The build starts with the light gray tiles making up the main chassis of the ship; it is quite a sturdy base to attach other parts of the ship to. Included in this build is a swing-down ramp mechanism for the rear cargo bay.

The blue canopy is built, with yellow transparent windows, to form the passenger and cargo compartments.

The underside of the ship is rather simple and generic - a few pillar and nozzle pieces to make up the landing gear. Compared to even slightly later ships such as Set 6929 Starfleet Voyager, the underside is outright primitive.

Nevertheless as a whole, this is a large spaceship (a foot or so in length) and it does take about two hours or so to build.

The control tower and the buggy are straightforward simple builds.

The completed model

Very imposing, between the size of the spaceship and the two base plates.

I like two features of the completed ship in particular: the design of the cargo compartment, which has wheel grooves and a ramp to allow the loading of the buggy onto the ship, and the roomy cockpit, which can take at least one passenger, or even two, in addition to the pilot. This makes the spaceship suitable for a number of different missions - perhaps a trip to a distant planet or asteroid so that the buggy can be taken there for exploration, or a trip back to Earth for the astronauts to take a vacation.

As is always the case with Lego products, this model works better in conjunction with other sets. In particular, I think the set works best when placed with other very early Classic Space sets with 3-digit set numbers, in particular Set 483 (Alpha-1 Rocket Base).

Summary

I now have sixteen Classic Space sets, which span the years from 1978 to 1984. Although the Galaxy Explorer is among the oldest of my collection, it still is easily the most spectacular and the most interesting. It was the original flagship of the Space line, and even compared to modern Lego sets (including ones for grownup collections), this set holds up extremely well. Thanks to well-designed compartments and four minifigures, this set offers lots of play possibilities.

The main concern with this set is finding a good example. Because of its age and high piece count, it is very difficult to find an example that is complete and in good condition, especially at reasonable prices. I lucked out by being the only bidder on an eBay auction, and even my complete set has some parts yellowing, a few incorrect replacement parts, and one cracked part. At least the incorrect replacement parts were replaced with correct ones once I got the set in my possession, so at least my example is complete, correct, and quite presentable now. Finding a decent example (or finding replacement parts, since most of the printed parts are no longer made new) will be quite a bit of work, but it will be worth it.

author: Faefrost
title: Possibly the single best most iconic Lego set ever!
review:
OK I know I write this one through the deep deep fog of nostalgia and remembrance of the 11 year old boy who first laid hands on one of these. But this is unarguably the best Lego set ever. This was ground zero for so many of us. This was the moment Lego stopped simply being building blocks and took us somewhere else. Someplace we could never actually go. Lego has always been a toy fueled by imagination. In this one moment Lego pried open our heads and poured in rocket fuel and pointed us to the stars. And nothing was the same again.

As far as the set itself? It remains a remarkable example of a truly well designed set that holds up quite well over time. The ship while a little blocky by todays standards is still amazingly sleek. The build remains solid and swooshable. While some of the classic space parts that it uses have proven to be a bit more fragile than Lego would have liked, over the years. I suspect this was more an effect of the sheer love and amount of play these sets received. Many of them have held up in good condition over the years. 

The baseplates remain the things of legend. Why oh why does Lego not give us more landing pad plates? The little control station sets the scene nicely. The buggy its little nesting thing of wonder. 

There are absolutely no negatives to this set save the shear prices that they can command on the aftermarket. My advice get a good used one for a lower price. Preferably a little faded, scuffed and play worn. Every mark on it was from someone loving it. Celebrate that joy of play.

author: Ignatius
title: The Holy Grail of Classic Space Lego
review:
Just looking at this set makes me smile. It evokes memories of spending time "snowed in" at a friends house and hours of fun with the galaxy explorer as the central figure. This set came out close to the release of Star Wars and it happily fed the imagination of an 11 yr old who was already getting into Sci- Fi. I vividly remember the Christmas morning when I opened it, I had asked for the smaller 487 Space Cruiser but my parents got this instead since it was bigger and looked cooler, I had no regrets! I ended up giving away all of my childhood lego collection and then as an adult when I started buying and selling on ebay, I realized that I could again own the sets I loved as a kid and with bricklink there to help me find those missing pieces or instructions, I was again hooked on space lego.

 

The whole classic space theme was as I understand it a new direction for Lego. It went beyond the chunky bricks and figures with bendy arms and introduced us to the minifig, to angled wings, to sleek design that really did evoke the spirit of what a space ship could be and setting everything on a dull grey lunar landscape just made it seem even more "out there". The way I see it, the classic space sets were the turning point for Lego into an even more imaginative direction and they set the groundwork for all the cool stuff that Lego makes today. It all started here folks.

 

OK so what is great about the Galaxy Explorer?

It has 4 minifigs and lots of accessories like wrenches and walkie talkies.

It carries a car inside....thats COOL!

It is BIG and heavy and was great to swoop around the room in imaginary flight.

It had its own landing pad and small control tower.

There was plenty of room on the wings to mount weapons: ( mine were the water cannons from the 1979 lego Fire boat!)

The design was futuristic: delta wing shapes and a pleasing shape that included hatches that open and the big back doors that could hold a car or several other lego-nauts for a mission.

The only thing I didnt like were the 3 big rockets on the bottom as they seemed clunky, I removed mine immediately and never looked back.

 

In terms of innovation, fun to play with, and good parts, I think that this set is the pinnacle of Lego Space, the first and the greatest.

author: Henno
title: Favorite set ever
review:
I was given this set by my Mum and Dad when I was 7yo

It was my favorite set ever and I think still is. The hours I spent playing and rebuilding this set are impossible to add up.  

It really is such a fantastic set that any and all AFOL should count as a must have. 

My one has become a favorite with my now 8yo son now even amongst all his and my lego sets from the past to present. And this set sits front and center in my Space/Star Wars theme only Lego display cabinet.

Thanks Mum and Dad xoxo

p.s. If you can get one do it.

author: rab1234
title: Classic Space at its Best
review:
Building Experience

I got 2 of these in a huge box of old sets so it was easier to find all of the pieces as compared with say the Cosmic Fleet Voyager, and build time was significantly less.  It's a unique build with more plates than I expected at the start and the time spent on the hull and moon base was less than I thought it would be.  That being said, the build kept my interest and certainly would have warranted 5 stars back in the early 80s when this was produced.

 

Parts

This is the one category that I need to deduct a star.  There are a lot of classic space elements like the gold windshields, radar dish, thrusters, and antenna.  However I have a gripe with the flimsy blue and gray tail and side fin pieces.  Several were broken and it's not just the age of the set.  I recall having a lot of these break when I had my original copy back in the day.  They require too much pressure to get them locked in place and the fin is too skinny.

 

Playability

The landing pad and base really add to the playability of this set.  The ship itself is also probably the best looking classic spaceship; very aerodynamic and sleek looking.  My only complaint would be the very small size of the base.  This could have been doubled without adding much to the overall cost of the set and would have looked much better and allowed for better play.

 

Value for the money

$32 back in 1980 (equivalent of about $90 today) may have seemed like a lot for 4 figures and 300 pieces, but you also got two base plates and one of the best looking lego ships that would be available for decades.  Considering that a used one goes for about $150 now, this would have been a great buy.  Is it worth $150 today?  As a collectible sure, but at about the same cost, it certainly can't hold up against something like 75105: Millennium Falcon

author: InvisibleTimmy
title: A True Gem
review:
The Galaxy Explorer is regarded by many as the paragon of Classic Space. 

 

Instructions 

Normal for a 70s or 80s set.

Minifigures

The set comes with two each of red and white spacemen

Build

This set is hard to build. The instructions ask you to put about ten bricks on per step, and I had to dismantle the ship twice to get it right.

Completed

Wow. This is a great-looking set. Even people who do not know what it is often remark upon how cool it looks. The ship itself is rather bulky, but still pretty sleek. The cockpit can seat two, or even three if you squeeze them in. The rear section fits the rover with a minifig on it. A really interesting subtle detail is that if you have a fig on the rover, it can be seen through the cargo bay windscreen.

The base is pretty nice too. The ship fits much better onto the landing pad than, say, the Galaxy Commander, and the base itself has all of those fancy printed computer bricks. The amount of figures included is also perfect for playability. You get two to pilot, one to drive the rover, and one to work in the base. Overall, everything about this set is totally perfect.

 

a review by InvisibleTimmy

author: Mr__Thrawn
title: Great, Even without the nostalgia
review:
497/928- Galaxy Explorer

The LL928 "Explorer" starship is the stuff of LEGO legend, and while many love it just for its nostalgic value, I'm going to try to review it as I would any other set. So, is the Galaxy Explorer worth the nearly $250 most charge for it? How does it stack up to modern sets in terms of design and playability? Read on to find out

Instructions

The instructions are normal for a set of this time period. They feature simple, but still well-done, images of the parts and model. They're a bit hard to follow, but are still of a relatively high quality.

 

Minifigures

There are four minifigures in this set. The red space man, of which there are two, features a classic space logo on his torso, and that generic, smiling,unisex face. The two white space men are essentially the same, but with a white torso, legs, air tanks, and helmet.

Build

Building this model is hard. It took about 2 hours, which is a long time for a 340-part set, and this is mainly due to the instructions asking you to put around 10 parts on per step. 

Completed

When completed, the set looks great. The ship is a little blocky by today's standards, but still sleek enough, and the moonbase is well done despite its small size. The famed baseplates are just as awesome as I expected, and it all just works.

Playability

The set has a good amount of stuff in it, and some basic play features, that make it a pretty good toy, as well as an awesome collector's item. The rear cargo bay opens, and the little rover can actually roll out, as opposed to today's "boarding ramps" that you have to shove a minifig up into. The moonbase has a lovely computer and communications dish to signal the rest of your fleet, and there is enough terrain around it for a minifig to explore. There is also a perfect amount of figs, because you have two to sit in the cockpit, one to sit on the rover in the cargo bay or on the terrain around the moonbase, and one to use the computers in the moonbase.

Parts

Lots of blue, grey, and trans yellow. There are some nice prints, and a trans-yellow plate.

 

Overall, this is both a great toy and a great display item.

author: LegoC8
title: Awesome Lego Set!
review:
My first  of two of my classic space sets. :)

 Pros:

- Extremely beautiful set with amazing color scheme.

-Has 4 minigs.

-Even has a landing pad and small base.

-Has a small Rover and even room in the spaceship to store it.

Cons:

- You can't close the cockpit to the ship with the minifigs standing up.

-Imstructions aren't as easy to follow as ones today.

Overall a very good set and definitely worth it's original price but is very expensive now. Glad I got mine for extremely cheap!
